title: Lazy Evaluation Using Recursive Python Generators
Using a Highly Dynamic Language for Development (2021)
description: Abstract: Games face an interesting challenge. They require rapid development, are highly interactive, and pose soft real-time performance constraints. While smaller games these days have also been developed in dynamic languages such as Python or Lua, traditionally engines are still written in static languages like C++ and C, with an additional scripting language on top to handle gameplay mechanics. Common Lisp offers an environment that‚Äôs both dynamic and performant enough to allow for a full stack game development system that is highly favourable to fast iteration and modular design.
description_plain:
**Abstract:** Games face an interesting challenge. They require rapid
development, are highly interactive, and pose soft real-time performance constraints. While smaller games these
days have also been developed in dynamic languages
such as Python or Lua, traditionally engines are still
written in static languages like C++ and C, with an
additional scripting language on top to handle gameplay mechanics. Common Lisp offers an environment
that‚Äôs both dynamic and performant enough to allow
for a full stack game development system that is highly
favourable to fast iteration and modular design.

title: Matchertext: an escape route from language-embedding hell?
LKRG - Linux Kernel Runtime Guard
description:
Linux Kernel Runtime Guard (LKRG) is a kernel module that performs runtime integrity checking of the Linux kernel and detection of security vulnerability exploits against the kernel.

  • LKRG 0.9.6 (2022-12-14) - mailing list announcement of recent version
  • lkrg-org/lkrg - source code

Additional resources:

  • Linux Kernel Runtime Guard (LKRG) in a nutshell (2020-08-13) - presentation about version 0.8
  • Historical Linux Kernel Runtime Guard (LKRG) wiki (2020-12-17) - exploit detection examples from old versions, no longer updated

Availability (quoting lkrg.org as seen on 2023-01-04):

LKRG packages exist in ALT Linux, Arch Linux, Astra Linux, Funtoo, Gentoo, Guix, NixOS, Whonix, and Yocto (and thus also OpenBMC). Whonix‚Äôs packaging is also usable for Debian and its other derived distributions (including Ubuntu).
description_plain:
Linux Kernel Runtime Guard (LKRG) is a kernel module that performs runtime integrity checking of the Linux kernel and detection of security vulnerability exploits against the kernel.

- [LKRG 0.9.6](https://www.openwall.com/lists/announce/2022/12/14/1) (2022-12-14) - mailing list announcement of recent version
- [lkrg-org/lkrg](https://github.com/lkrg-org/lkrg) - source code

Additional resources:

- [Linux Kernel Runtime Guard (LKRG) in a nutshell](https://www.openwall.com/presentations/OSTconf2020-LKRG-In-A-Nutshell/) (2020-08-13) - presentation about version 0.8
- [Historical Linux Kernel Runtime Guard (LKRG) wiki](https://openwall.info/wiki/p_lkrg/Main) (2020-12-17) - exploit detection examples from old versions, no longer updated

Availability (quoting lkrg.org as seen on 2023-01-04):

> LKRG packages exist in [ALT Linux](https://packages.altlinux.org/en/sisyphus/srpms/kernel-source-lkrg), [Arch Linux](https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/lkrg-dkms/), [Astra Linux](https://dl.astralinux.ru/astra/stable/orel/repository/pool/main/l/lkrg/), [Funtoo](https://code.funtoo.org/bitbucket/projects/AUTO/repos/security-kit/browse/app-antivirus/lkrg?at=refs%2Fheads%2Fnext), [Gentoo](https://packages.gentoo.org/packages/app-antivirus/lkrg), [Guix](https://packages.guix.gnu.org/packages/lkrg/), [NixOS](https://search.nixos.org/packages?channel=unstable&from=0&size=50&sort=relevance&type=packages&query=lkrg), [Whonix](https://www.whonix.org/wiki/Linux_Kernel_Runtime_Guard_LKRG), and [Yocto](https://git.yoctoproject.org/meta-security/tree/recipes-kernel/lkrg) (and thus also [OpenBMC](https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/plugins/gitiles/openbmc/openbmc/+/refs/heads/master/meta-security/recipes-kernel/lkrg/)). Whonix's packaging is also usable for Debian and its other derived distributions (including Ubuntu).

title: Generalized LL (GLL) Parser
description:
This post provides a complete tour of Generalized LL (GLL) parsing along with GSS (graph structured stack) and extraction of parse trees from SPPF (shared packed parse forest). This is part of my ongoing effort to document various parsing algorithms.

I am looking for feedback on structure as well as content as before.

Note: Pyodide takes a little time to initialize, but it should be faster to initialize than spinning up the binder service from Jupyter (but slower to execute).

This is the writeup.
description_plain:
This post provides a complete tour of Generalized LL (GLL) parsing along with GSS (graph structured stack) and extraction of parse trees from SPPF (shared packed parse forest). This is part of my ongoing effort to document various parsing algorithms.

I am looking for feedback on structure as well as content as before.

Note: Pyodide takes a little time to initialize, but it should be faster to initialize than spinning up the binder service from Jupyter (but slower to execute).

[This is the writeup.](https://rahul.gopinath.org/post/2022/07/02/generalized-ll-parser/)
